questions.text: Peak in cardiac output antenatally occurs at
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Cardiac output rises by ~30–50% during pregnancy
  • The maximum increase is observed at 28-30 weeks, then plateaus
  • 20-22 wk: Increase ongoing but not at peak (Option B ruled out)
  • 32-34 wk: Peak already surpassed; levels off (Option C ruled out)
  • 36-38 wk: May show slight decline due to vena cava compression (Option D ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • 28-30 weeks is the peak period for antenatal cardiac output
  • Physiologic changes support increased uterine blood flow
  • Later stages may see reduced venous return from mechanical compression

questions.text: According to WHO, anemia in pregnancy is diagnosed, when hemoglobin is less than
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • WHO defines anemia in pregnancy as hemoglobin <11.0 gm%
  • This cutoff accounts for hemodilution due to increased plasma volume
  • 10.0 gm%: Below diagnostic threshold, hence incorrect (Option A ruled out)
  • 12.0 gm%: Normal range for non-pregnant women; too high for anemia definition (Option C ruled out)
  • 9.0 gm%: Indicates moderate anemia, not the diagnostic cutoff (Option D ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • <11.0 gm% is the WHO cutoff for anemia in pregnancy
  • Accounts for physiologic changes in blood volume during gestation
  • Used globally for screening and classification

questions.text: Which of the following tests is most sensitive for the detection of iron depletion in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Serum ferritin reflects body iron stores and is the earliest and most sensitive indicator of iron depletion

Explanation of other options:

Serum iron (Option A): Fluctuates with diet and inflammation; not reliable for early diagnosis

Serum transferrin (Option C): Increases in iron deficiency but is nonspecific

Serum iron binding capacity (Option D): Rises later in deficiency; not as sensitive as ferritin

Key Takeaways:

  • Serum ferritin is the most sensitive marker of iron depletion
  • Used to detect early-stage iron deficiency
  • Other iron studies are less reliable for early detection

choices.text: Combined iron and folic acid deficiency

questions.text: A 37 years multipara construction labourer has a blood picture showing hypochromic anisocytosis. This is most likely indicative of:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Hypochromic anisocytosis indicates variation in RBC size and decreased hemoglobin content, consistent with a mixed deficiency
  • Common in economically disadvantaged multiparas due to combined nutritional deficits

Explanation of other options:

Iron deficiency (Option A): Causes microcytic hypochromic anemia but not significant anisocytosis alone

Folic acid deficiency (Option B): Produces macrocytosis without hypochromia

Malnutrition (Option C): Nonspecific term; not a definitive hematologic diagnosis

Key Takeaways:

  • Hypochromic anisocytosis points to combined deficiencies
  • Seen in high-risk populations like multiparas in poor socioeconomic settings
  • Mixed anemia patterns should prompt evaluation for both iron and folate

questions.text: In pregnancy, which type of anemia is not common in India?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Vitamin B12 deficiency is not commonly seen in Indian pregnant women
  • Iron and folic acid deficiencies are significantly more prevalent due to dietary insufficiency and increased maternal demands

Explanation of other options:
Folic acid anemia (Option B): Common due to poor intake and increased requirement
Iron + folic acid anemia (Option C): Frequently observed in multiparas and undernourished women
Iron deficiency anemia (Option D): Most prevalent form of anemia in Indian pregnancy

Key Takeaways:

  • Vitamin B12 anemia is not a common type in India
  • Iron and folate are the leading deficiencies in pregnant women
  • Focus of public health programs is on iron-folic acid supplementation

questions.text:
Thirty years old G4P3L3 with 32 weeks pregnant with a single live fetus in cephalic presentation, Patient complains of easy fatigability and weakness since the last 3 months which has gradually increased over the last 15 days to an extent that she gets tired of doing household activities. Patient also complains of breathlessness on exertion since the last 15 days. Patient gets breathless on climbing 2 flights of stairs. It is not associated with palpitations or any chest pain. There is no history of pedal edema, sudden onset breathlessness, cough or decreased urine output. There is no history of asthma or chronic cough. There is no history of chronic fever with chills or rigors. There is no history of passage of worms in stool nor blood loss from any site. There is no history of easy bruisability or petechiae. There is no history of yellow discoloration of urine, skin or eyes. She did not take iron folate prophylaxis throughout her pregnancy.
She is suspected to be anemic and her blood sample was ordered for examination which showed.
Hb 7.4 gm% (12-14 gm%)M
Hct 22% (36-44%)
MCV 72 fL (80-97 fL)
MCH 25 pg (27-33 pg)
MCHC 30% (32-36%)
Peripheral smear shows microcytic hypochromic RBCs with anisopoikilocytosis Naked eye single tube red cell osmotic fragility test (NESTROFT) is negative. What is the most probable diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Low Hb, Hct, MCV, MCH, and MCHC indicate microcytic hypochromic anemia
  • Peripheral smear supports the diagnosis with anisopoikilocytosis
  • NESTROFT negative makes thalassemia trait unlikely
  • Patient has classic symptoms of iron deficiency anemia and a history of no iron prophylaxis

Explanation of other options:

Thalassemia (Option A): Ruled out by negative NESTROFT and lack of target cells

Megaloblastic anemia (Option C): Would show macrocytic RBCs and possibly hypersegmented neutrophils

Vitamin B12 deficiency anemia (Option D): Typically macrocytic, not microcytic

Key Takeaways:

  • Iron deficiency anemia is the most common anemia in pregnancy
  • Negative NESTROFT helps exclude thalassemia trait
  • Microcytic indices are hallmark for iron deficiency, not B12 or folate deficiency

choices.text: Oral iron can be given only if anemia is detected before 20 weeks of pregnancy
Parenteral iron therapy markedly increases the reticulocyte count within 7-14 days
Parenteral therapy is ideal during 30-36 weeks
Blood transfusion may be useful in severe anemia beyond 36 weeks

questions.text: The following statements are related to the therapy of iron deficiency anemia except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Oral iron can be administered anytime during pregnancy once anemia is diagnosed
  • Parenteral iron increases reticulocyte count within 7-14 days indicating effective therapy
  • Parenteral therapy is ideal during 30-36 weeks for rapid correction
  • Blood transfusion is useful in severe anemia beyond 36 weeks or urgent cases

Key Takeaways:

  • Oral iron therapy is not limited to early pregnancy
  • Parenteral iron and transfusion are reserved for later pregnancy or severe anemia
  • Treatment choice depends on severity and gestational age

questions.text: The following are related to the treatment of thalassaemia except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Routine iron therapy is not indicated in thalassemia; patients often develop iron overload due to repeated transfusions.
  • Fresh blood transfusion is preferred to reduce iron load and complications
  • Folic acid supplementation is necessary due to increased erythropoiesis
  • Deferoxamine is an iron chelator that improves outcomes by reducing iron overload in pregnancy

Explanation of other options:
Fresh (relatively) blood transfusion (Option A): Used to minimize iron overload and alloimmunization
Folic acid (Option B): Needed to support increased red cell production
Deferoxamine improves pregnancy outcome (Option D): Chelation therapy beneficial in pregnancy with thalassemia

Key Takeaways:

  • Iron overload management is critical in thalassemia; avoid routine iron therapy
  • Folic acid and transfusions support effective erythropoiesis
  • Chelation with deferoxamine is essential to prevent complications

questions.text: All are used for contraception in sickle cell anemia except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Oral contraceptive pills, IUCDs, and progestin-only pills or implants are all used safely for contraception in sickle cell anemia patients
  • No method listed is contraindicated, so none of the above is the correct choice

Explanation of other options:
Oral 'Pill' (Option A): Safe and effective in sickle cell anemia
IUCD (Option B): Widely used and safe contraceptive method
Progestin only pill or implant (Option C): Preferred in some cases due to lower thrombosis risk

Key Takeaways:

  • Multiple contraceptive options are available and safe for sickle cell anemia patients
  • Choice depends on individual risk factors and pReferences: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page 731s
  • No absolute contraindication among listed methods

questions.text: With oral iron therapy, rise in Hb% can be seen after:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Hemoglobin rises by 0.7-1 gm per week with oral iron therapy
  • Significant rise typically seen after 3 weeks of treatment initiation
  • Lack of improvement by 3 weeks suggests need for diagnostic re-evaluation

Explanation of other options:
1 week (Option A): Too early to see a significant Hb rise
4 weeks (Option C): Hb rise starts earlier; 3 weeks is standard timeframe
6 weeks (Option D): Hb should have risen well before this

Key Takeaways:

  • Hb rise of 3 gm/dL/week or more indicates response
  • Assess response by 3 weeks to guide further management
  • Delay in improvement warrants investigation of other causes

questions.text: Raised MCV in pregnancy can be due to:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Megaloblastic anemia causes macrocytosis leading to raised MCV
  • Alcohol use is a known cause of macrocytosis and increased MCV
  • Hypothyroidism can also cause elevated MCV
  • All these conditions contribute to raised MCV in pregnancy

Explanation of other options:

Megaloblastic anemia (Option A): True but not the only cause

Alcohol use (Option B): Causes raised MCV

Hypothyroidism (Option C): Associated with increased MCV

Key Takeaways:

  • Raised MCV in pregnancy has multiple etiologies
  • Consider nutritional, toxic, and endocrine causes
  • Important for accurate diagnosis and management

questions.text: Which of the following parameters will fall the earliest in iron deficiency?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Among red cell indices, MCV (mean corpuscular volume) falls earliest in iron deficiency
  • Serum ferritin is the earliest biochemical marker, but among indices, MCV changes first
  • MCH, MCHC, and RDW change later in the progression of iron deficiency

Explanation of other options:

MCH (Option B): Falls after MCV changes

MCHC (Option C): Changes later and less sensitive

Red cell distribution width (Option D): Increases later due to variation in RBC size

Key Takeaways:

  • MCV decrease is the earliest red cell index change in iron deficiency
  • Serum ferritin is the most sensitive biochemical indicator
  • Monitoring indices helps in early detection of anemia

questions.text: Which of the following hematological criteria remains unchanged in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • MCHC (mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration) remains relatively unchanged during pregnancy
  • Blood volume increases significantly in pregnancy (Option A ruled out)
  • Total iron binding capacity (TIBC) increases due to increased transferrin production (Option B ruled out)
  • Serum ferritin usually decreases as iron stores are utilized (Option D ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • MCHC is stable and a reliable parameter in pregnancy
  • Pregnancy causes physiological changes in blood volume and iron metabolism
  • Understanding these changes is essential for anemia diagnosis

questions.text: Not an indicator for blood transfusion:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Moderate anemia at 24-30 weeks is usually managed medically, not an indication for transfusion
  • Severe anemia at 36 weeks requires transfusion due to risks near term
  • Blood loss anemia necessitates transfusion to restore volume and oxygen-carrying capacity
  • Refractory anemia not responding to treatment is an indication for transfusion

Key Takeaways:

  • Blood transfusion is reserved for severe, refractory, or blood loss anemia
  • Moderate anemia before third trimester is typically managed with iron therapy
  • Correct timing of transfusion is critical for maternal and fetal well-being

questions.text: How much iron a patient can tolerate at a time given intravenously?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Maximum intravenous iron tolerated at a time is 2500 mg (50 ml × 50 mg/ml)
  • If dose exceeds this, it is split over two days
  • Iron sorbitol is preferred for safety over iron dextran

Key Takeaways:

  • Maximum safe IV iron dose is 2500 mg per day
  • Larger doses require division over multiple days
  • Choice of preparation affects safety profile

questions.text: Dose of folic acid per day for treating megaloblastic anemia in pregnancy:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • 1 mg/day is the standard dose to treat megaloblastic anemia in pregnancy
  • 400 mcg/day is for prevention of neural tube defects
  • 4 mg/day is used in women with previous history of neural tube defects or sickle cell disease.

Key Takeaways:

  • Treatment of megaloblastic anemia requires 1 mg folic acid daily
  • Higher doses reserved for high-risk pregnancies
  • Preventive doses are lower at 400 mcg daily

questions.text: All are the complications of anemia except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Gestational diabetes is not a complication of anemia
  • Anemia is linked to preeclampsia, infection, IUGR, and other serious maternal and fetal complications

Explanation of other options:
Pre eclampsia (Option A): Associated with anemia-induced placental insufficiency
IUGR (Option C): Due to reduced oxygen delivery to fetus
Infection (Option D): Anemia impairs immune response, increasing infection risk

Key Takeaways:

  • Anemia causes significant maternal and fetal morbidity
  • It contributes to hypertensive disorders, infections, and poor fetal growth
  • Gestational diabetes is unrelated to anemia

questions.text: Which of the following iron preparations cannot be used intramuscularly?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Parenteral iron therapy is indicated in severe anemia cases especially in the last 8-10 weeks of pregnancy, malabsorption syndromes, or dialysis patients
  • Intramuscular iron preparations include:
    • Iron dextran
    • Ferric carboxy maltose
    • Iron sucrose
  • Iron sorbitol cannot be given intramuscularly; it is administered intravenously only
  • Administration details for intramuscular iron:
    • Test dose: 50 mg
    • Full dose: 100 mg daily or alternate day
    • Injection site: upper outer quadrant of buttock
    • Use Z-track method with a thick needle to avoid staining and irritation
  • Intravenous iron dextran:
    • Test dose: 0.5 ml
    • Full dose either as multidose therapy (2 ml/day = 100 mg elemental iron) or single dose diluted in 500 ml saline and infused slowly
  • If dose > 2500 mg (50 ml × 50 mg elemental iron/ml), divide into two infusions on consecutive days
  • Parenteral iron causes the same Hb rise as oral iron (~0.7-1 gm% per week), main advantage is certainty of dose delivery

Explanation of other options:

Iron dextran (Option A): Approved for intramuscular and intravenous use

Ferric carboxy maltose (Option C): Approved for intramuscular use

None of the above (Option D): Incorrect, because iron sorbitol cannot be given IM

Key Takeaways:

  • Iron sorbitol is contraindicated for intramuscular injection
  • Parenteral iron is preferred when oral therapy is inadequate or not tolerated
  • Proper technique and dosing schedules are essential to minimize side effects

questions.text: What is the dose of folic acid in patients with sickle cell diseases?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In sickle cell disease during pregnancy, folic acid supplementation of 4-5 mg daily is recommended to support increased red blood cell turnover
  • Additional management includes:
    • Prophylactic penicillin V 250 mg twice daily
    • Controversial use of prophylactic blood transfusions to maintain hematocrit >25% and HbS <60%
    • Hydroxyurea is not recommended during pregnancy
  • Regular monitoring of Hb, hematocrit, platelet count, bilirubin, transaminases, and LDH is necessary
  • Vaginal delivery preferred, with epidural analgesia during labor
  • Postnatal thromboprophylaxis for up to 6 weeks may be indicated

Key Takeaways:

  • High-dose folic acid (4 mg/day) is essential in sickle cell pregnancy
  • Management requires multidisciplinary approach and close monitoring
  • Avoid hydroxyurea during pregnancy due to teratogenicity

questions.text: Which of the following features indicates the presence of heart disease in pregnancy and which is not seen in normal pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Distended neck veins indicate cardiac disease due to elevated central venous pressure and are not seen in normal pregnancy
  • Exertional dyspnea is common in normal pregnancy due to increased oxygen demand (Option A ruled out)
  • Systemic hypotension is not typical in pregnancy but can occur; however, it is less specific (Option C ruled out)
  • Pedal edema is frequent in pregnancy due to fluid retention and venous stasis (Option D ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Distended neck veins are a key sign of heart disease in pregnancy
  • Other symptoms like dyspnea and pedal edema may be physiological in pregnancy
  • Careful evaluation needed to distinguish normal changes from pathology

questions.text: Maximum strain of parturient heart occurs during:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Distended neck veins indicate raised central venous pressure, a sign of heart disease, and are not seen in normal pregnancy
  • Normal cardiovascular changes in pregnancy include:
    • Increased blood volume and cardiac output leading to physiological exertional dyspnea
    • Peripheral vasodilation causes systemic hypotension which is not indicative of heart disease
    • Venous stasis and fluid retention lead to pedal edema, a common physiological finding
  • These correlations explain why exertional dyspnea, systemic hypotension, and pedal edema are normal findings, thus eliminating them as indicators of heart disease

Explanation of other options:

Exertional dyspnea (Option A): Due to increased oxygen demand in pregnancy, common and physiological

Systemic hypotension (Option C): Result of vasodilation during pregnancy; not specific for heart disease

Pedal edema (Option D): Caused by venous pooling and increased fluid volume; common and physiological

Key Takeaways:

  • Distended neck veins are a clear clinical sign of cardiac pathology in pregnancy
  • Other listed features are physiological adaptations and not diagnostic of heart disease
  • Recognizing these distinctions aids accurate clinical assessment

questions.text: In a pregnant woman with heart disease, all of the following are to be done except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • IV methergine is contraindicated in pregnant women with heart disease due to its vasoconstrictive and hypertensive effects
  • Other measures are important for managing cardiac patients postpartum:
    • Prophylactic antibiotics to prevent infections
    • IV furosemide postpartum to manage fluid overload and prevent heart failure
    • Cutting short the second stage of labor to reduce cardiac stress

Mnemonic for contraindications of Methergine - TOPER:

  • T: Toxemia (pre-eclampsia)
  • O: Organic heart disease
  • P: Pregnancy-induced hypertension
  • E: Epilepsy
  • R: Renal disease

Explanation of other options:

Prophylactic antibiotics (Option B): Prevent infective endocarditis and puerperal infections

IV furosemide postpartum (Option C): Controls volume overload in cardiac patients

Cut short 2nd stage of labor (Option D): Minimizes cardiac workload

Key Takeaways:

  • Methergine is contraindicated in heart disease due to risk of hypertensive crisis
  • Proper postpartum management includes fluid control and infection prevention
  • Mnemonic TOPER aids quick recall of methergine contraindications

questions.text: In which of the following heart diseases is maternal mortality during pregnancy found to be the highest:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Eisenmenger syndrome develops due to secondary pulmonary hypertension from a left-to-right cardiac shunt reversing to right-to-left, causing cyanosis
  • It carries the highest maternal mortality (~50%) during pregnancy among heart diseases
  • Pregnancy is contraindicated in Eisenmenger syndrome due to poor prognosis
  • If diagnosed in the first trimester, termination of pregnancy is advised
  • Most common cause of death is right ventricular failure with cardiogenic shock

Explanation of other options:

Coarctation of aorta (Option A): Increased risk but lower mortality than Eisenmenger syndrome

Aortic stenosis (AS) (Option C): Moderate risk, better prognosis

Mitral stenosis (MS) (Option D): Common but maternal mortality is lower compared to Eisenmenger syndrome

Key Takeaways:

  • Eisenmenger syndrome has the worst maternal prognosis in pregnancy
  • Early diagnosis is crucial to counseling and management
  • Maternal death usually occurs from right heart failure

choices.text: Marfan syndrome with dilated aortic root

questions.text: Normal pregnancy can be continued in:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Wolf-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome is usually compatible with continuation of pregnancy with proper management

Explanation of other options:

Primary pulmonary hypertension (Option A): Pregnancy is contraindicated due to high maternal risk

Eisenmenger syndrome (Option C): Very high maternal mortality; pregnancy contraindicated

Marfan syndrome with dilated aortic root (Option D): Risk of aortic rupture; pregnancy often contraindicated if severe dilation

Key Takeaways:

  • WPW syndrome can be safely managed during pregnancy
  • Other conditions listed pose significant maternal risks and generally contraindicate pregnancy
  • Multidisciplinary care is crucial for management

questions.text: Most common heart disease associated with pregnancy is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In developing countries like India, the most common heart disease in pregnancy is rheumatic heart disease
  • Among rheumatic lesions, mitral stenosis accounts for about 80% of cases, making it the most prevalent
  • Mitral regurgitation and aortic stenosis follow in frequency
  • In developed countries, congenital heart diseases are more common, with atrial septal defect being the most frequent

Explanation of other options:

Mitral regurgitation (Option B): Common but less than mitral stenosis in rheumatic cases

Patent ductus arteriosus (Option C): Less common in pregnancy

Tetralogy of Fallot (Option D): Rare in pregnancy due to cyanotic nature and poor survival

Key Takeaways:

  • Mitral stenosis is the predominant heart disease in pregnant women in developing countries
  • Etiology varies geographically with rheumatic vs congenital causes
  • Knowledge of regional prevalence aids diagnosis and management

questions.text: Indications for cesarean section in pregnancy are all except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Eisenmenger syndrome is not an absolute indication for cesarean section; vaginal delivery is usually preferred to reduce cardiovascular stress
  • Aortic stenosis, aortic aneurysm, and aortic regurgitation may warrant cesarean section to avoid the hemodynamic burden of labor

Explanation of other options:

Aortic stenosis (Option B): Cesarean may be indicated to prevent cardiac complications during labor

Aortic aneurysm (Option C): Cesarean preferred to prevent rupture risk during labor

Aortic regurgitation (Option D): Severe cases may require cesarean to reduce volume overload

Key Takeaways:

  • Delivery mode in cardiac patients is individualized based on lesion severity
  • Vaginal delivery is favored in Eisenmenger syndrome due to high risks with cesarean

questions.text: In heart patient the worst prognosis during pregnancy is seen in:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Aortic stenosis carries a worse prognosis in pregnancy due to the risk of left ventricular outflow obstruction, heart failure, and arrhythmias
  • Mitral regurgitation usually has a better outcome because of decreased afterload in pregnancy (Option A ruled out)
  • Mitral valve prolapse is generally well tolerated (Option B ruled out)
  • Pulmonary stenosis tends to be mild and well tolerated in pregnancy (Option D ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Severe aortic stenosis poses a high risk during pregnancy
  • Other valve lesions generally have better maternal outcomes
  • Close monitoring and management are essential for cardiac patients in pregnancy

questions.text: A 25-year-old female admitted with septic abortion is diagnosed with tricuspid valve endocarditis. Which organ is most likely to be affected by embolization from the valve vegetation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Tricuspid valve endocarditis involves the right side of the heart
  • Emboli from right-sided vegetations enter the pulmonary circulation, affecting the lungs
  • Liver, spleen, and brain are commonly affected by emboli from left-sided endocarditis, not right-sided

Explanation of other options:

Liver (Option A): Left-sided emboli can cause liver infarcts, not typical for tricuspid valve disease

Spleen (Option B): Splenic emboli occur with left heart involvement

Brain (Option C): Cerebral emboli arise from left-sided vegetations

Key Takeaways:

  • Right-sided endocarditis leads to pulmonary septic emboli
  • Embolic complications depend on the side of heart involved
  • Important to distinguish right vs left-sided involvement for clinical management

questions.text: A full-term pregnant woman with known mitral stenosis and mitral regurgitation is planned for normal vaginal delivery. What is the preferred anesthesia technique for labor analgesia in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Pain relief is critical in heart disease patients to prevent tachycardia and cardiac failure
  • Epidural and spinal anesthesia (collectively called neuraxial analgesia) provide effective, region-specific pain relief during labor
  • These regional techniques limit systemic stress and maintain hemodynamic stability
  • Neuraxial analgesia (epidural) is the anesthesia of choice in heart disease during pregnancy.
  • In patients with heart disease and intracardiac shunts, general anesthesia (GA) is preferred due to risk of paradoxical embolism with neuraxial techniques

Explanation of other options:

Parenteral opioids (Option A): Less effective and may cause respiratory depression

Spinal anesthesia (Option B): Part of neuraxial but single-shot spinal may cause rapid hypotension

Inhalational analgesia (Option C): Less commonly used, not preferred in heart disease

Key Takeaways:

  • Epidural (neuraxial) analgesia is preferred for labor in heart disease patients
  • GA preferred if intracardiac shunts are present
  • Effective pain control reduces cardiac workload and complications

questions.text: A prosthetic valve patient switches to heparin at which time of pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In patients with mechanical prosthetic valves, anticoagulation management during pregnancy is critical
  • Warfarin is used between 12 and 36 weeks but carries fetal risks (embryopathy, miscarriage, IUGR)
  • Heparin (unfractionated) is used:
    • Up to 12 weeks (to avoid teratogenicity)
    • From 36 weeks onwards to reduce bleeding risk during delivery
  • Heparin is safe for the fetus as it does not cross the placenta but is less effective than warfarin for thromboprophylaxis
  • Heparin is continued until 6 hours before delivery and restarted postpartum (6 hours after vaginal delivery, 24 hours after cesarean)
  • Warfarin is not contraindicated during breastfeeding

Explanation of other options:

28 weeks (Option A) and 32 weeks (Option B): Too early to switch from warfarin to heparin

Postpartum (Option D): Heparin is given before delivery as well to manage bleeding risk

Key Takeaways:

  • Switch from warfarin to heparin at 36 weeks to minimize peripartum bleeding
  • Use unfractionated heparin in early and late pregnancy; warfarin in the middle trimester
  • Careful timing reduces maternal and fetal risks
